description: US Troops leave Nicaragua during the Banana Wars (1933)
Decision to start the January Uprising (1863)
long_description:
3rd of January Central National Committe, the underground coordinating committee of the Polish independence movement in 1860s Congress Poland, decided to start an uprising against tsarist Russia. The uprising itself started 22nd of January but that date was taken by Lunar New Year.

Although the Uprising fell and didn't achieve anything substantial it was an enormous moment for Polish nation-building, art and literature.

The drawing shows the night when the fateful decision was made, faced with the order of forced conscription into Russian army, the Polish combatants decided that this was the last chance for independence. The viewer can see two Poland clays, one is sewing a flag of the January Uprising — white-crimson-blue horizontal tricolour with tri-partie coat of arms featuring Polish white eagle, Lithuanian Vytis, and Ruthenian Archangel Micheal — the other is ripping apart paper with tsar's order.

On a wall we see szlachta's saber, symbol of Polish military and defaced portrait of tsarist Russia (black-yellow-white) with captions "LIAR", "THIEF", "BANDIT", "TYRANT" in Polish.

The artwork was made with substantial help by users Canadapple (lighting and shadows) and Paulionm (shape of the flag's cloth).

Featured here is the Shwedagon Pagoda. The art is a replication of Burmese lacquer art. At the foreground is a Burmese looking back at the temple and is reminded of their magnificent history and culture.

description: First demonstration of the telegraph and morse code (1838)
long_description:
Here, we see America demonstrating the telegraph for the first time in 1838.

For your ease of translation, the message on the ribbon is, in morse code: (.---- ---.. -.... ...-- ---... / - .... . / .--. . --- .--. .-.. . ... .----. / ..-. .. .-. ... - / -- .- .--. -.-.--).

Note: the Wikipedia article didn't have any information about the nationality of the victims (besides Turkey), so I did further research to find out about that.

Based on modern day independence day celebrations.

During the Lantern Festival, children go out at night carrying paper lanterns and solve riddles on lanterns hanging outside. It is a time of togetherness and people eat Tang Yuan (glutinous rice balls with different fillings) to bring the family harmony, happiness and luck in the new year. 

Lantern riddles are also seen during the Mid-Autumn festival, and as the Lantern festival and the Mid-Autumn Festival both have themes of lanterns and togetherness they both have ‘Lantern Festival’ as an alternate names, and should not be mixed up as they are different festivals.

The Treaty of Waitangi was first signed on 6 February 1840. The treaty was signed by representatives acting on behalf of the British Crown and, initially, about 45 Māori chiefs, and then grew to over 500 Maori chiefs and representatives of the British Crown.

Over the course of the next seven months, copies of the treaty were toured around the country to give other chiefs the opportunity to sign. By the end of September, around 540 Maori chiefs had signed the Maori version of the Treaty.

The signing had the effect of securing British sovereignty over the islands of New Zealand, which was officially proclaimed on 21 May 1840.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waitangi_Day

description: The End of the Battle of the Alamo (1836)

long_description:
Israel, inside of a synagogue, reads the story of Esther as written in the Torah.

In the thought bubble are the four main characters from the book of Esther. King Ahasuerus (wearing the crown and holding the scepter), queen Esther (wearing a crown and a bow), and Mordecai (wearing a ribbon) are furious with Haman (wearing the gold star).

Behind them are the Jews that have been saved from genocide.

The king and Haman are represented by the flag of the Achaemenid Empire, AKA the first Persian Empire. The king is wearing a crown based off of some drawings of Cyrus the Great. He is holding the scepter because the scepter is an important part of the story of Esther (he holds the scepter out to Esther to indicate he will not kill her). Haman is wearing a gold star to indicate that he is an important official (specifically, the viceroy to the king).

Mordecai and Esther are played by Israel because they are Jews (along with all the characters in the background). Mordecai is wearing a ribbon because he had previously saved the king's life and is in the king's favor.

North Macedonia (then called the Republic of Macedonia) was only accepted into the UN a full 18 months after its independence. This was because Greece strongly objected to the nation's use of the name of Macedonia.

As a compromise, the nation was officially called "the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" on a provisional basis. Greece also objected to the flag of the country, as it was thought to be a Greek symbol.

As such, only after the nation changed its flag to the current one did the Macedonian flag fly over the UN headquarters.

In April 11th, 1623, the Western faction dethroned King Gwanghae, installing Prince Neungyang on the throne. Neungyang's reign name would be Injo.

This coup set Joseon firmly in the pro-Ming camp in the ongoing Ming-Manchu conflict, paving the way for future Manchu invasions.

Every monarch of Joseon from this point onwards would be descended from Injo, making this coup one of the possible points that divide the early period of the dynasty from the later period.

The Brazilian constitutional referendum (1993) was held on 21 April 1993 to determine the form of government of the country. After the re-democratization of Brazil, an article in the new Constitution determined the holding of a referendum for voters to decide if the country should remain a republic or become a monarchy again.
Also known as the Dhaka garment factory collapse

On this day in 1953, Watson and Crick published their discovery of the double helix structure of DNA in an article titled "A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid," in the scientific journal Nature. The structure was discovered via X-ray crystallography performed by Rosalind Franklin, and the image she generated with this technique, simply titled "Photo 51", is considered by some to be the most important image in the history of humanity.

This day celebrates the first post-apartheid elections held in South Africa held in 1994. Previously, under apartheid, non-whites had only limited voting rights. Black South Africans in particular were not allowed to vote at all.

description: High levels of Chernobyl radiation detected in Sweden (1986)
long_description: The radiation was detected on a shoe, which is why that is also depicted on there. In the background there's the Chernobyl plant and the general layout of the Baltic Sea between Sweden and the Ukrainian SSR.

In the background is the American flag, formed by the stars, clouds, mountains, and reflections in the water.

The mountains represent the Rockies and the Appalachians respectively, and the water represents the notion of America extending "from sea to shining sea".

The evergreen trees to the left represent the forests of the west coast, and the oak tree to the right is the national tree, and also represents the deciduous forests of the east coast.

In the foreground, we see America and several states enjoying a typical 4th of July celebration. And in the front, we see a rosebush - America's national flower.

The Battle of Kursk was a major World War II Eastern Front engagement between the forces of Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union near Kursk in the southwestern USSR during late summer 1943; it ultimately became the largest tank battle in history.

description: Beginning of the Prince of Ning Rebellion (1519)

long_description:
This artwork commemorates the 80th anniversary of the Bloody Sunday when the Ukrainian Insurgent Army death squads aided by the local Ukrainian peasants simultaneously attacked at least 99 Polish settlements within the Wołyń Voivodeship of the prewar Second Polish Republic under the German occupation.

This tragedy remains one of the thorns in the Polish-Ukrainian relations despite them immensely improving since the Russian invasion on the former.
The artwork is divided in two parts.

On the lower Poland solemnly submits a grave candle to a grave with a catholic cross, while Ukraine waits with its own grave candle while looking apologetically at Poland. On the upper part we can see a flashback of the Bloody Sunday drawn with only shades of red, where blood-coated Ukraine skewers Poland with a pitchfork and screams "Death to Poles" in Ukrainian.

Thanks to u/magicalgirldittochan for improving the lighting effects.

Paknam incident was a short naval battle where the French sailed their gunboats through Siamese blockade. The whole affair was deeply humiliating for Siam, especially since the battle was one-sided due to incompetence of the native sailors who didn't know how to operate guns and didn't understand commands shouted by Andreas du Plessis de Richelieu, the western admiral Siamese king brought from Denmark.

This panel is of the Treaty of Bucharest of 1913, which ended the 2nd Balkan War. It is a figurative piece, depicting the event metaphorically. Romania, the country hosting the conference, is depicted as a chef, pointing out choice cuts of Bulgaria on a sign for a future meal, with the other treaty participants gathering around it like hungry patrons picking and choosing their shares. The cuts in question are representations of territorial losses Bulgaria incurred via the treaty. Turk-Fed represents the fact that a lot of these territories were seized by Bulgaria during the prior 1st Balkan War against the Ottomans.

I slept on this panel for a day after getting it to this state, hoping some kind of inspiration would strike, but nothing came of it, and honestly, I'm actually pretty happy with the result. Hope it's cool to everyone looking at it.

description: Establishment of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (1948)
long_description: The area north of the 38th parallel continued to use the Taegeukgi, just like the southern half of Korea, until 1948. The current North Korean flag was adopted in 1948. It was designed by the Soviet Union, who objected to a socialist republic having a flag based on Chinese superstition.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is the world's largest and highest-energy particle accelerator, and was a joint project between many European nations in the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN). It is used to research the fundamental nature of our universe, and most famously was used to experimentally detect the existence of the Higgs Boson - a particle whose existence proves our physical theories of how matter gets its mass.

Battle of Vienna is a famous battle when Polish hussars commanded by Jan III Sobieski broke the Ottoman siege of Vienna halting the turkish incursion into South-Eastern Europe.

The artwork features a humorous caricature where Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth wearing a cook's hat sits in a döner kebab stand and slices of a piece of Ottoman Empire impaled on a metal stick as if it was a piece of kebab.

Before the stand Hungary, Habsburg Empire, Bohemia, Venetian Republic, Holy Roman Empire, and Cossack Hetmanate are looking gleefully waiting for their portion of meat. In the far background Vienna can be seen.

description: Independence day (Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador, Costa Rica)
long_description:
Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, El Salvador, and Costa Rica gained independence from Spain with the Act of Independence of Central America, ratified on this day in 1821. The day is now celebrated as independence day in these countries.

In this panel, each country runs free from Spain atop their national animals.

description: Autumnal Equinox/First day of Fall (Northern Hemisphere)

long_description:
While the first and the third partitions were officially ratified in specific days, the second one happened in parts. Prussia and Russian Empire made plans to further divide Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in 23rd of January. Grodno Sejm that ratified the cessions was held between 17th of June and 23rd of November. Cession to Russia was made official in 22 July and the prussian cession in 23rd of September or 25th of September depending on sources.

The artwork shows dismembered PLC laying on Castle Square sidewalk in the puddle of blood and scraps of the Constitution of 3rd of May.  Prussia and Russia walk away, each holding a bloody piece leaving red smears. USA is observing the situation making notes in a book titled "Federalist Papers". Turkey, United Kingdom, Austria, France, and Spain look the other way uninterested. Behind the Commonwealth a broken podium lays. It's raining and the dim grey lighting sets a grim mood.

This is the mid-autumn festival, celebrated by many cultures that were influenced by Chinese mythology.

I drew Chang'e, the goddess of the moon, who is the patron goddess of the festival. She famously has a pet rabbit. Above are lanterns, which can be seen everywhere during mid-autumn celebrations. Below are mooncakes, which are traditionally eaten during the festival.
Artstyle is heavily inspired by traditional basket weaving patterns in Botswana.

After the end of the War, Austria was occupied by the four Allied forces (Soviet Union, United States, Great Britain, and France), who divided the country into four zones.

The capital Vienna was also divided in four, with the historic central district being jointly administered by the “Allied Control Council”. Although the Austrian parliament was democratically elected, every legislative regulation or political action of the government at first required consent by the Allied Control Council and later on could still be vetoed by it.

The negotiations over a State Treaty putting an end to the occupation could finally be concluded in the spring of 1955: the Austrian State Treaty was signed on May 15, 1955, in Vienna's Schloss Belvedere and entered into force on July 27, 1955.

On October 26, 1955, the Austrian Parliament passed the constitutional law on permanent neutrality, which has been celebrated as the Austrian National day since 1965.

And Last We have South africa Being Represented as a victim of a flesh eating Alien-Parasite-Thing also known as Lesotho, while South Africa is in Agony because of the Parasite eating its flesh and bones Lesotho has found an escape to the open world to feast on new victims.

The Morris Worm was one of the earliest computer worms, and the first to gain widespread public attention due to its impact. The program itself was intended purely as a harmless academic exercise, but ended up crippling a significant portion of the internet at the time, because it excessively duplicated itself and caused its host computers to slow to a halt.

description: Creation of the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (1990)
long_description: The motif on the left is called Okir, an indigenous woodcarving design hailing from the southern Philippines, particularly the Maranao tribe. The creation of the autonomous region was the first step of self-determination of what is now Bangsamoro, a region whose history and culture persisted through colonization and Philippine independence. Here we can see the nation looking towards its heritage as the Philippine sun sets on the right.

Festival of Onam is a harvest Festival in the State of Kerala. In the panel, a pookalam is depicted. A pookalam is a pattern made using petals, leaves, and flowers and is traditionally done during Onam.

Due to some reason, the panel preview below is being artifacted and pixelated.

description: End of National Novel Writing Month (International)
long_description:
National Novel Writing Month (NaNoWriMo) is an international self-driven challenge to write a novel (defined as a 50,000 word work of fiction) in the month of November. This day is the last day of NaNoWriMo.

In the picture, we have America - where the event was first established - wearing the NaNoWriMo signature blue viking helmet, and participants from several other countries that participate in the challenge. In the background are excerpts from three different published novels that were first drafted during NaNoWriMo: "Water for Elephants", "Fangirl", and "The Night Circus".
On this day, the Monroe Doctrine is first elaborated in a annual message to congress by president Monroe.

description: Patent issued for the hurricane lantern (1878)
long_description:
Three inventors are shown here. In the front John W. Orphy (New York, USA), the inventor of the iconic design known today as "hurricane lantern" (1878); behind him John H. Irwin (Pennsylvania, USA), the inventor of the hot-blast and cold-blast mechanism used in the lantern (1873); inside the house sits Ignacy Łukasiewicz (Galicia, Austrian Poland), the inventor of kerosene lamps in general although his design couldn't be used outdoors (1853).

The artwork features New York state and Pennsylvania going out into a storm holding "hurricane lanterns" kerosene lamps that could be used in bad whether while Galicia stays indoors holding a simple desktop lamp.

Thanks to u/magicalgirldittochan for help with the lighting.
